_prev_prog_2.EquipmentTested: Storage tank, relief valves, excess flow valves, piping, hoses, pump

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
EXECUTIVE SUMMARY

POMEROY GRAIN GROWERS, INC.

We are a fertilizer retail facility.  The only materials considered hazardous at this facility are anhydrous ammonia and aqua (a 20 wt% solution of ammonia in water).  Our facility has one 25,000-gallon tank for storing anhydrous, and one 15,000 gallon and one 30,000-gallon tank for storing aqua, equipment for receiving anhydrous and aqua by truck, and equipment for transferring anhydrous and aqua from storage to trucks for delivery to customers.  It is our policy to meet, or exceed, all local, state, and national standards relating to handling ammonia.

Specific safety features that we employ to minimize the impact of an accidental release include:

1.  Excess flow valves to prevent flow from a tank or truck if any anyhdrous hose or line breaks.
2.  Pressure relief valves on the anhydrous storage tanks to prevent overpressuring and rupturing the tanks.
3.  Diking around the aqua storage area, to contain accidental aqua spills.

Site-specific process safety information is tabulated below.

(Relief valves) See GENERAL, fire occurs at or around storage facility.

What if?:			Transport temperature gauge malfunctions?
Consequence:		Potential to deliver more ammonia than tank should hold.  Potential for storage tank to be overfull when temperature rises, potential to overpressure and damage storage tank, potential to release ammonia.
Safeguards:		Relief valves on ammonia storage tank protect against overpressure.
Recommendaton:		(Relief valves) See GENERAL, fire occurs at or around storage facility.

HOSES/CONNECTIONS			
What if?:			Liquid transfer hose valve leaks?	
Consequence:		Potential ammonia release.  Potential personnel exposure. 
Safeguards:		Tank area is diked to contain spill and minimize rate of evaporation.  Operator wears protective gloves and safety goggles, ammonia odor.  Gas masks and water trough.
Recommendation:		Ensure that gas mask canisters are up-to-date.

What if?:			Vapor transfer hose valve leaks?
Consequence:		Potential ammonia release.  Potential personnel exposure.
Safeguards:		Operator trained to check valves, operator wears protective gloves and safety goggles, ammonia odor, gas masks and water trough.
Recommendation:		See HOSES/CONNECTIONS, liquid transfer hose valve leaks.

What if?:			Liquid hose disconnected before transport valve shut?
Consequence:		Potential ammonia release.  Potential personnel exposure.	
Safeguards:		Hose and transport valves located at disconnect point of transfer hose, to facilitate quick valve closing and minimize release.  Excess flow valve on transport.  Operator wears protective gloves and safety goggles, ammonia odor.  Gas masks and water trough.	
Recommendations:	See HOSES/CONNECTIONS, liquid transfer hose valve leaks.

What if?:			Vapor hose disconnected before transport vapor valve shut?	
Consequence:		Potential ammonia release.  Potential personnel exposure.
Safeguards:		Hose and transport valves located at disconnect point of transfer hose, to facilitate quick val

A third party Hazard Analysis of our facility was performed by Sentry Engineering and reviewed by Shannon & Wilson, Inc. in June 2004.  Results are tabulated below.

ANHYDROUS STORAGE HAZARD ANALYSIS

GENERAL			
What if?:			Fire occurs at or around storage facility?
Consequence:		Potential to overheat and overpressure storage tanks, potential tank damage an/or release of ammonia.	
Safeguards:		Relief valves on storage tank protects against overpressure.
Recommendation:		Ensure that flammable materials are farther than 10 ft from tank.  Ensure that relief valves have been replaced or rebuild within the past 5 years.  Ensure rain caps on all relief valves.

What if?:			Flood occurs at storage facility?
Consequence:		Potential to lift and damage tanks and/or lines, potential  release of ammonia.	
Safeguards:		Excess flow valves on storage tanks minimize release of ammonia.
Recommendation:		Safeguards adequate.

What if?:			Storage facility is hit by tornado?
Consequence:		Potential to lift and damage tank and/or lines, potential  release of ammonia.
Safeguards:		Excess flow valves

on storage tanks minimize release of ammonia.	
Recommendation:		Safeguards adequate.

What if?:			Facility is hit by lightning?	
Consequence:		Potential to damage tank, piping, or equipment.  Potential release of ammonia.
Safeguards:		Excess flow valves on storage tanks minimize release of ammonia.  Tank is grounded.
Recommendation:		Safeguards adequate.

What if?:			There is a power outage?
Consequence:		Potentially unable to load or unload.  No safety consequences.
		
What if?:			Vehicle impacts facility?
Consequence:		Potential to damage tank, piping, or equipment.  Potential release of ammonia.
Safeguards:		Tank located far from roadway.	
Recommendation:		Consider protecting tank with a barricade or posts.

TRANSPORT			
What if?:			Transport contains something other than aqua?	
Consequence:		Potential to contaminate aqua storage, potential to overheat and damage tank from heat of reaction.
Safeguards:		Agreement with supplier to only supply aqua.  Relief valves on storage tank  protect against overpressure.
Recommendation:		(Relief valves) See GENERAL, fire occurs at or around storage facility.

What if?:			Transport rolls during loading/unloading?
Consequence:		Potential to break lines to storage tanks, potential release of ammonia.
Safeguards:		Driver chocks wheels and sets brake prior to connecting hoses.  Excess flow valves.
Recommendation:		Safeguards adequate.

What if?:			Transport leaves before disconnecting hoses?
Consequence:		Potential to break lines to storage tanks, potential release of ammonia.  
Safeguards:		Excess flow valves.
Recommendation:		Safeguards adequate.

What if?:			Transport level gauge malfunctions?
Consequence:		Potential to overfill storage tank, potential to overpressure and damage storage tank, potential to release ammonia.  
Safeguards:		Driver present during the filling procedure, level gauge on the storage tank, relief valves on storage tank prevents overpressure and damage. 
Recommendation:

ve closing and minimize release.  Excess flow valve on transport.  Operator wears protective gloves and safety goggles, Ammonia odor.  Gas masks and water trough.	
Recommendations:	See HOSES/CONNECTIONS, liquid transfer hose valve leaks.

What if?:			Liquid hose disconnected before facility liquid vapor transfer valve shut?	
Consequence:		Potential ammonia release.  Potential personnel exposure.	
Safeguards:		Hose and transport valves located at disconnect point of transfer hose, to facilitate quick valve closing and minimize release.  Excess flow valve on transport.  Operator wears protective gloves and safety goggles, ammonia odor. Ammonia Odor.  Gas masks and water trough.
Recommendations:	See HOSES/CONNECTIONS, liquid transfer hose valve leaks.

What if?:			Vapor hose disconnected before facility vapor transfer shut?
Consequence:		Potential ammonia release.  Potential personnel exposure.	
Safeguards:		Hose and transport valves located at disconnect point of transfer hose, to facilitate quick valve closing and minimize release. 	Excess flow valve on transport.  Operator wears protective gloves and safety goggles, ammonia odor.  Ammonia Odor.  Gas masks and water trough.	
Recommendation:		See HOSES/CONNECTIONS, liquid transfer hose valve leaks.

What if?:			Vapor hose ruptures?
Consequence:		Potential ammonia release.  Potential personnel exposure.
Safeguards:		Excess flow valves.  Operator wears protective gloves and safety goggles.  Gas masks and water trough.	
Recommendation:		See HOSES/CONNECTIONS, liquid transfer hose valve leaks.

What if?:			Liquid hose ruptures?
Consequence:		Potential ammonia release.  Potential personnel exposure.
Safeguards:		Excess flow valves.  Operator wears protective gloves and safety goggles  Gas masks and water trough.	
Recommendation:		See Hoses/Connections, Liquid transfer hose valve leaks.

PUMP/COMPRESSOR			
What if?:			Pump seal leaks?
Consequence:		Potential ammonia release.	
Safeguards:		Block val

ve located on suction and discharge of pump to isolate leak.  Operator present during pump  operation.
Recommendation:		Safeguards adequate

What if?:			Pump suction plugged?
Consequence:		Potential to damage pump, potential seal leak, potential release of ammonia.	
Safeguards:		Block valves located on suction and discharge of pump to isolate leak.  Operator present during pump  operation.
Recommendation:		Safeguards adequate

What if?:			Pump discharge plugged?	
Consequence:		Potential to damage pump, potential seal leak, potential release of ammonia.  
Safeguards:		Block valves located on suction on discharge of pump to isolate leak.  Operator present during pump  operation.	
Recommendation:		Safeguards adequate

AMMONIA STORAGE TANKS
What if?:			Storage tank overfilled to overflowing?
Consequence:		Potential to overpressure and/or damage storage tank, potential release of ammonia.
Safeguards:		Driver present during filling procedure, tank nearly empty before filling and tank capacity greater than  transport capacity.  Relief valves on storage tank to prevent overpressure and damage.
Recommendation:		(Relief Valves)  See GENERAL, fire occurs at or around storage facility.

What if?:			Storage tank overfilled but not overflowing?
Consequence:		Potential to overpressure and/or damage storage tank when ambient temperature rises, potential release of ammonia.
Safeguards:		Driver present during filling procedure, tank nearly empty before filling and tank capacity greater than  transport capacity.  Relief valves on storage tank to prevent overpressure and damage.
Recommendation:		(Relief Valves)  See GENERAL, fire occurs at or around storage facility.

What if?:			Liquid line to storage tank blocked in liquid full?
Consequence:		Potential to overpressure and damage line/hose, potential to release ammonia. 
Safeguards:		Hydrostatic relief valves installed in lines with potential to be blocked in liquid full, excess flow valves in  line on storag

e tank.
Recommendation:		Safeguards adequate.

What if?:			Storage tank level gauge malfunctions?
Consequence:		Potential to overfill storage tank, potential overpressure and/or damage storage tank, potential release of  ammonia.
Safeguards:		Driver present during filling procedure, tank nearly empty when filled and tank volume is greater than  transport volume.  Relief valves on storage tanks to prevent overpressure and damage.
Recommendation:		(Relief Valves)  See GENERAL, fire occurs at or around storage facility.

What if?:			Storage tank temperature gauge malfunctions?
Consequence:		Potential to overfill storage tank, potential overpressure and/or damage storage tank, potential release of  ammonia.
Safeguards:		Driver present during filling procedure, tank is nearly empty before filling and tank capacity is greater than transport capacity.  Relief valves on storage tank to prevent overpressure and damage.
Recommendation:		(Relief Valves)  See GENERAL, fire occurs at or around storage facility.

What if?:			Storage tank has excess corrosion/erosion?
Consequence:		Potential for storage tank to crack, rupture or leak, potential release of ammonia.	
Safeguards:		Storage tank is well maintained, painted and routinely visually inspected.	
Recommendation:		Safeguards adequate.

What if?:			Relief valve fails to lift when needed?
Consequence:		Potential to overpressure and damage the storage tank, potential ammonia release.
Safeguards:		Relief valves inspected annually, and replaced every 5 years.
Recommendation:		See GENERAL, fire occurs at or around storage facility.

What if?:			Relief valve lifts below set pressure?
Consequence:		Potential ammonia release through relief valve.
Safeguards:		Relief valves inspected annually, and replaced every 5 years.
Recommendation:		See GENERAL, fire occurs at or around storage facility.

What if?:			Relief valve fails to reseat?
Consequence:		Potential release of ammonia.
Safeguards:		Relief valves i

protects against overpressure.
Recommendation:		Consider reviewing shipping papers prior to unloading.

What if?:			Transport rolls during loading/unloading?
Consequence:		Potential to break lines to storage tanks, potential release of ammonia.
Safeguards:		Area is diked to prevent spreading of spill and to minimize rate of evaporation.  Excess flow valves on transport. Driver chocks wheels and sets brake prior to connecting hoses.	
Recommendation:		Safeguards adequate.

What if?:			Transport leaves before disconnecting hoses?
Consequence:		Potential to break lines to storage tanks, potential release of ammonia.	
Safeguards:		Area is diked to prevent spreading of spill and to minimize rate of evaporation. Excess flow valves on transport.  Driver chocks wheels and sets brake prior to connecting hoses.	
Recommendation:		Safeguards adequate.

What if?:			Transport level gauge malfunctions?	
Consequence:		Potential to overfill storage tank, potential to overpressure and damage storage tank, potential to release ammonia.
Safeguards:		Driver present during the filling procedure, level gauge on the storage thank, relief valves on storage tank prevents overpressure and damage. 
Recommendations:	Safeguards adequate.

HOSES/CONNECTIONS			
What if:			Liquid transfer hose valve leaks?
Consequence:		Potential ammonia release.  Potential personnel exposure.
Safeguards:		Tank area is diked to contain spill and minimize rate of evaporation.  Operator wears protective gloves and safety goggles, ammonia odor.  Gas masks and water trough.	
Recommendation:		See ANHYDROUS STORAGE, Hoses/Connections, liquid transfer hose valve leaks.

What if?:			Liquid hose disconnected before transport liquid valve shut?
Consequence:		Potential ammonia release.  Potential personnel exposure.	
Safeguards:		Hose and transport valves located at disconnect point of transfer hose to facilitate quick valve closing and minimize release.  Operator trained to check valves.  Excess flow

valve on transport.  Operator wears protective gloves and safety goggles, ammonia odor.  Gas masks and safety shower.	
Recommendation:		See ANHYDROUS STORAGE, Hoses/Connections, liquid transfer hose valve leaks.

What if?:			Liquid hose ruptures?	
Consequence:		Potential ammonia release.  Potential personnel exposure.	
Safeguards:		Excess flow valves.  Hose and transport valves located at disconnect point of transfer hose, to facilitate quick valve closing.  Tank area is diked to contain spills and minimize rate of evaporation. Operator wears protective gloves and safety goggles.  Ammonia Odor.  Gas masks and water trough.	
Recommendation:		See ANHYDROUS STORAGE, Hoses/Connections, Liquid transfer hose valve leaks.

PUMP/COMPRESSOR			
What if?:			Pump seal leaks?
Consequence:		Potential ammonia release.
Safeguards:		Block valve located on suction and discharge of pump to isolate leak.  Operator present during pump operation.
Recommendation:		Safeguards adequate.

What if?:			Pump suction plugged?	
Consequence:		Potential to damage pump, potential seal leak, potential release of ammonia.	
Safeguards:		Block valves located on suction and discharge of pump to isolate leak.  Operator present during pump operation.
Recommendation:		Safeguards adequate.

What if?:			Pump discharge plugged?
Consequence:		Potential to damage pump, potential seal leak, potential release of ammonia.
Safeguards:		Block valves located on suction on discharge of pump to isolate leak.  Operator present during pump operation.
Recommendation:		Safeguards adequate.

AQUA STORAGE TANKS
What if?:			Storage tank overfilled?
Consequence:		Potential to overpressure and/or damage storage tank, potential release of ammonia.
Safeguards:		Driver present during filling procedure, tank nearly empty before filling and tank capacity greater than transport capacity.  Atmospheric vent on storage tank to prevent overpressure and damage. Tank area is diked to contain spills and minimize r

ate of ammonia release.	
Recommendation:		Safeguards adequate.

What if?:			Liquid line to storage tank blocked in liquid full?
Consequence:		Potential to overpressure and damage line/hose, potential to release ammonia. 
Safeguards:		Hydrostatic relief valves installed in lines with potential to be blocked in liquid full, excess flow valves in line on storage tank.	
Recommendation:		Safeguards adequate.

What if?:			Storage tank level gauge malfunctions?
Consequence:		Potential to overfill storage tank, potential overpressure and/or damage storage tank, potential release of ammonia.	
Safeguards:		Driver present during filling procedure, tank nearly empty when filled and tank volume is greater than transport volume.  Atmospheric vent on storage tank to prevent overpressure and damage.  Tank area is diked to contain spills and minimize rate of ammonia release.
Recommendation:		Safeguards adequate.

What if?			Storage tank has excess corrosion/erosion?
Consequence:		Potential for storage tank to crack, rupture or leak, potential release of ammonia.
Safeguards:		Storage tank is well maintained, painted and routinely visually inspected.
Recommendation:		Safeguards adequate.

To further ensure safe operation of the facility, our employees are trained in procedures for safe handling of hazardous materials, and in safe operating and maintenance procedures.  

Operating Procedures are as follows:

OPERATING PROCEDURES

NURSE TANK/TRUCK LOADING FROM BULK STORAGE

WARNING:		Ammonia can be very harmful if inhaled.
                      		Ammonia can cause eye, skin, and respiratory tract burns. 
			ALWAYS wear filter mask or splash goggles when working on ammonia lines.
			ALWAYS wear rubber/Neoprene safety gloves when working on ammonia lines.
			ALWAYS vent line away from you.

CAUTION:     		Never leave transfer operation unattended.
			If necessary to leave area, find a qualified person to attend the operation, or stop the operation.
	
1.

Ensure that gas masks and protective clothing are readily available.
2. Spot the nurse tank/truck in loading area.
3. Ensure nurse tank/truck in chocked.
4. Remove nozzle caps on nurse tank/truck nozzles.

If necessary, clean connector with a rag and replace worn or damaged gaskets or O-rings.

5. Connect liquid and vapor hoses.

CAUTION:  		Never drag a hose connector or valve across the ground.
			Never carry a valve by the handwheel or operating lever.

			Always carry by the valve body, with the outlet pointed way from your body.

6. Ensure that liquid and vapor valves on storage tank are open.
7. Ensure that pump/compressor suction and discharge valves are open.
8. Open vapor and liquid hose valves.
9. Open vapor and liquid valves on nurse tank/truck.
10. Start pump/compressor.

WARNING:      		If a leak or fire occurs, stop pump immediately.
                         		Leak:  If possible, stop leak.  If not possible, STOP OPERATION.
                         		Fire:    If possible, extinguish with fire extinguisher.  If not possible CONTACT FIRE DEPARTMENT.

11. When filling level is reached, stop pump/compressor.
12. Close vapor and liquid valves on nurse tank/truck.
13. Close vapor and liquid hose valves.
14. Either:
	A. Crack connection to release pressure, or
	B. Open bleeder valve to release pressure.
15. Disconnect and store hose.
16. Replace caps on nurse tank/truck hose nozzles.

AQUA LOADING FROM BULK STORAGE

WARNING:     		Ammonia can be very harmful if inhaled.
                        		Ammonia can cause eye, skin, and respiratory tract burns. 
                  		ALWAYS wear filter mask or splash goggles when working on ammonia lines.
                  		ALWAYS wear rubber/Neoprene safety gloves when working on ammonia lines.
                  		ALWAYS vent line away from you.

CAUTION:     		Never leave transfer operation unattended.
                      		If necessary to leave area, find a qualified perso

n to attend the operation, or stop the operation.

1. Ensure that gas masks and protective clothing are readily available.
2. Get paper work and information about what truck to load from.
3. Determine last load truck, and have truck washed out if necessary.
4. Ensure truck is placarded for aqua.
5. Spot the truck in loading area.
6. Ensure truck is chocked.
7. Ensure truck vent is open.
8. Remove nozzle cap on truck nozzle.

If necessary, clean connector with a rap and replace worn or damaged gaskets or O-rings.

9. Connect hose.

CAUTION:    		Never drag a hose connector or valve across the ground.
			Never carry a valve by the handwheel or operating lever.
			Always carry by the valve body, with the outlet pointed away from you body.

10. Ensure that valve on storage tank is open.
11. Ensure that pump suction and discharge valves are open.
12. Open hose valve.
13. Open valve on truck.
14. Start pump

WARNING:      		If a leak or fire occurs, stop pump immediately.
                        		Leak:  If possible, stop leak.  If not possible, STOP OPERATION.
                         		Fire:    If possible, extinguish with fire extinguisher.  If not possible CONTACT FIRE DEPARTMENT.

15. When filling level is reached, stop pump.
16.  Close valve on storage tank.
17. Close valve on truck.
18. Close truck vent valve.
19. Close hose valve.
20. Place drip bucket under hose and either:
	A) Crack connection to release pressure, or
	B) Open bleeder valve to release pressure.
21. Disconnect and store hose.
22. Replace cap on truck hose nozzle.
23.Take copies of completed paper work to operations manager's office.

Our Maintenance Policy includes:

1. Employees performing maintenance are trained to safely maintain storage tanks and equipment, and are certified as required by the Training Policy.
2. Maintenance contractors are required to certify that their employees are qualified to perform job tasks in a safe manner.
3. Equipment is

bolts.
8. Spread flanges to relieve any residual pressure.
9. Remove bolts, separate flanges, and remove gaskets.
10. Remove coupling or drive belt.
11. Loosen base mount bolts.
12. Remove pump/compressor.  If necessary use hoist or crane to prevent injury when removing pump/compressor.

Replace Pump/Compressor
1.	Inspect pump/compressor flanges for scratches or defects.	

NOTE:     	Do not reinstall pump/compressor with badly scratched or galled flanges.

2. Clean flanges if necessary.
3. Ensure bolts are proper grade and length.
4. Apply anti-seize compound to bolts.
5. Place pump/compressor back on base mounts.  Use rigged hoist/crane if necessary.  Tighten base mount bolts in start pattern two or three time to ensure a solid foundation.
6. Insert flange bolts and new gaskets.
7. Tighten flange bolts in cross pattern.
8. Repeat tightening pattern to ensure that all bolts are tight.  (If tightening pattern not repeated, seals may be inadequate and may leak.)
9. Align and replace coupling or drive belt.
10. Reconnect electrical wiring to pump/compressor.
11. Return pump/compressor breaker to the 'ON' position and test the pump/compressor to ensure the wiring was reconnected correctly.
12. Open block valves and allow line to pressure with aqua and check for leaks.
13. Clean and store tools.

REMOVE/REPLACE MANIFOLD RELIEF VALVE

WARNING:	Ammonia can be very harmful if inhaled.
		Ammonia can cause eye, skin, and respiratory tract burns.
		Always wear splash goggles when working on aqua lines.
		Wear rubber/neoprene safety gloves when working on ammonia fittings.
		Always vent line away from you.

This procedure involves danger from working on top of the storage tank.

WARNING:     	Always have another person in attendance during this procedure.  NEVER perform this procedure unattended.

1. Ensure that water shower or water tub is available.
2. Ensure that gas masks and protective clothing are readily available.
3. Close manifold

port for valve to be removed.
4. Open bleed valve to bleed off any pressure from valve to be removed
5. Using open end or adjustable wrench, remove valve.
6. Remove any dust caps, plus, or covers from replacement valve.
7. Clean valve mounting threads with cleaning solvent approved for ammonia.

Take care to prevent contacting internal valve parts.

8. Chase manifold female threads with proper size pipe tape.

CAUTION:    	If pipe tap binds, stop chasing.  Do not force the tap.

9. Clean manifold threads with cleaning solvent approved for ammonia.
10. Apply thread sealing compound to male valve threads, removing any excess compound with clean rag.

Ensure that compound is approved for ammonia service by checking container label.

11. Carefully screw valve into manifold.

Avoid cross threading.  After screwing in hand tight, tighten with open end or adjustable wrench.  Do not tighten valve more than 1/2 turn with wrench.

12. Close bleed valve.
13. Open manifold port.
14. Return tank to service and check for leaks.
If new valve does not work properly.
	A) Close the manifold port for the defective valve.
	B) Open bleed valve to bleed off any pressure.
	C) Remove the defective valve.
	D) Replace the old valve until an acceptable valve can be obtained.
	E) Close bleed valve.
	F) Open manifold port and return tank to service.
15.  Clean and store tools.

REMOVE/REPLACE FLANGE GASKET

WARNING:     	Ammonia can be very harmful in inhaled.
                         	Ammonia can cause eye, skin, and respiratory tract burns.
		Always wear splash goggles when working on ammonia lines.
		Wear rubber/neoprene safety gloves.
		Always vent line away from you.

Remove Gasket:

WARNING:	Before removing/replacing gasket, ensure that line segment is vented to atmospheric pressure.

NOTE:		Procedure, INSTALLING VALVES covers installing gaskets directly on tanks.

1. Ensure that gas masks and protective clothing are readily available.
2. E

RNING:     	Ammonia can be very harmful if inhaled.
                        	Ammonia can cause eye, skin, and respiratory tract burns.
                        	Always wear splash goggles when working on aqua lines.
                        	Wear rubber/neoprene safety gloves.

Remove Hydrostatic Relief Valve:

WARNING:     	Before removing/replacing hydrostatic relief valve, ensure that the line segment is vented to atmospheric pressure.

1. Ensure that gas masks and protective clothing are readily available.
2. Ensure line segment, which includes hydrostatic valve, is isolated from any energy source (i.e. block valves are closed and locked and pump motor breaker is locked off).
3. If there is a valve to vent the line, open valve and allow line to vent.  (If there is NO valve to vent the line, the line segment may be vented from a gasketed flange as described in Step 4.)
4. Loosen the flange bolts on the side of flange opposite from you (to direct any spray, from residual contents in line, away from you).  Gently pry the flange apart, but only far enough to start the line segment venting.
If the line does not stop venting, check to make sure no other lines are venting into the line segment.  If there are no other lines the block valve must be leaking and the bulk storage tank must be emptied before removing the relief valve.

NOTE:      	Procedure, REMOVING AMMONIA FROM TANKS, covers depressurizing tanks.

5. After venting the line segment, the hydrostatic relief valve may be removed by unscrewing it from the line.  A channel lock or pliers may be needed.

CAUTION:    	If line not adequately cleaned or purged, STOP, and return to step 3.

Replace Hydrostatic Relief Valve:
1. Inspect new hydrostatic relief valve for debris or defects.

NOTE:  		Do not reinstall hydrostatic relief valve after removing from the line.

2. Clean valve threads with cleaning solvent approved by ammonia.
Take care to prevent solvent contacting internal valve parts

3. Clean line threads with cleaning solvent approved by ammonia.
4. Apply thread sealing compound to male threads.
Ensure that compound is approved for ammonia service by checking container label.
5. Carefully screw threaded valve onto line.

Avoid cross threading.  After screwing in hand tight, tighten with open end or adjustable wrench.  Do not tighten valve more than 1/2 turn with wrench.

6.  Open block valve and allow line to pressure with ammonia and check for leaks.
7. Clean and store tools.

INSTALLING THREADED GAUGES/VALVES ON STORAGE TANKS

WARNING:       	Ammonia can be very harmful if inhaled.
                          	Ammonia can cause eye, skin, and respiratory tract burns.
		Always wear splash goggles when working on aqua lines.
                         	Wear rubber/neoprene safety gloves.
                         	Always vent line away from you.

WARNING:     	Before removing/replacing a pump or compressor, ensure that the line segment is vented to atmospheric pressure.

1.  Ensure that gas masks and protective clothing are readily available.
2.  Remove any dust caps, plugs, or covers from replacement valve.
3.  Clean valve mounting threads with cleaning solvent approved for ammonia.

Take care to prevent contacting internal valve parts.

CAUTION:     	Before installing gauge/valve, ensure that tank is empty and at 0 psig pressure, unless gauge is mounted in well that protects the gauge from contents in the tank.

NOTE:           	Procedure:  REMOVING AMMONIA FROM TANKS covers depressurizing tanks.

4. Remove existing tank gauge/valve, nozzle cover or cap.
5. Chase container female threads with proper size pipe tap.

CAUTION:    	If pipe tap binds, stop chasing.  Do not force the tap.

6. Clean container threads with cleaning solvent approved by ammonia.
7. Apply thread sealing compound to male valve threads, removing any excess compound with clean rag.
Ensure that compound is approved for ammonia service by che

rt/nurse tank is chocked.
5. Connect vapor and liquid hoses.
If necessary, clean connectors with a rag and replace worn or damaged gaskets or O-rings.

CAUTION:     	Never drag a hose connector or valve across the ground.
                       	Never carry a valve by the handwheel or operating lever.
		Always carry by the valve body, with the outlet pointed away from your body.

6. Ensure that liquid and vapor valves at storage tank are open.
7. Ensure that pump suction and discharge valves are open.
8. Open liquid and vapor valves.
9. Open liquid and vapor valves on transport/nurse tank.
10. Start pump.

WARNING:    	If a leak of fire occurs, stop pump and close valves immediately.
                       	Leak:  If possible, stop leak.  If not possible, STOP OPERATION.
                       	Fire:    If possible, extinguish with fire extinguisher.  If not possible, CONTACT FIRE DEPARTMENT.

11. Remove liquid ammonia until either:
	A) All liquid is removed (pump will start to cavitate), or
	B) Transport/nurse tank is 85% full.
12.  Stop pump.
13. Close liquid and vapor valves on transport/nurse tank.
14. Close liquid and vapor hose valves.
15. Close liquid and vapor valves at storage tank.
16. Crack liquid and vapor hose connections to allow pressure to bleed off.
17. After pressure has bled from lines, disconnect vapor and liquid hoses.

WARNING:     	After liquid is removed, vapor remaining in the tank may cause dangerously high pressure to remain in the tank.

Follow the next procedure to remove vapor remaining in tank.

Remove Residual Ammonia Vapor:

WARNING:  	Always wear splash goggles when working on ammonia lines.
                     	Wear rubber/neoprene safety gloves.
                     	Always vent lines away from you.

This procedure transfers  pressurized ammonia vapor from the storage tank to water in a transport or storage tank, where the ammonia is absorbed into water.

CAUTION:   	Considerable heat is ev

olved when ammonia dissolves in water.  To avoid overheating and damaging the transport or receiving storage tank, be sure that at least 5000 gal of water is in the transport or receiving storage tank.

1. If vapor is transferred to a vehicle, ensure that vehicle contains water, is chocked, and approved for ammonia and aqua.
2. Connect liquid hose to vehicle, trough, or storage tank containing water.
3. Open pump bypass valves.
4. Slowly open liquid hose valve.
5. If transfer is to a vehicle, open liquid valve on vehicle.
6. Monitor vapor transfer by observing pressure on the ammonia storage tank pressure gauge.

CAUTION:     	If strong ammonia odor occurs before pressure decreases to 0 psig, solution has probably become saturated with ammonia.  In this case close valves on liquid line, dispose of the solution, refill water, and repeat steps 2 through 6.

7. When pressure gauge indicates 0 psig, close all valves.
8. Open vent or vapor valve on storage tank to relieve any remaining pressure.
9. Disconnect and store hose.
10. Dispose of ammonia solution according to company policy.

Our Training Policy is as follows:

EMPLOYEE TRAINING POLICY

This company complies with state and U.S. Department of Transportation (DOT) rules governing training.

All persons operating ammonia/aqua processes are certified as having the knowledge, skills, and abilities to safely perform duties and responsibilities associates with ammonia/aqua processes.  Training certifications are on record in the company office.

Refresher skills training is provided at least tri-annially.

Initial and refresher HAZMAT training are provided for persons involved with ammonia/aqua operations.

Employees are trained in major process changes before operating the changed process.

We have also coordinated with the Garfield County Volunteer Fire Department to respond in the unlikely event of an emergency.

Our Emergency Response Policy is described below.

EMERGENCY RESPONSE

nspected annually, and replaced every 5 years.	
Recommendation:		See GENERAL, fire occurs at or around storage facility.

AQUA STORAGE HAZARD ANALYSIS

GENERAL			
What if?:			Fire occurs at or around storage facility?
Consequence:		Potential to overheat and overpressure storage tanks, potential tank damage and/or release of ammonia.
Safeguards:		Grass, brush, flammables kept a minimum of 10 feet from storage tanks.  Vents on storage tank protect  against overpressure.
Recommendation:		Safeguards adequate.

What if?:			Flood occurs at storage facility?
Consequence:		Potential to lift and damage tanks and/or lines, potential release of ammonia.	
Safeguards:		Tanks are anchored, area is diked to prevent spreading of spill and to minimize rate of evaporation.
Recommendation:		Safeguards adequate.

What if?:			Storage facility is hit by a tornado?
Consequence:		Potential to lift  and damage tank and/or lines, potential release of ammonia.	
Safeguards:		Tanks are anchored, area is diked to prevent spreading of spill and to minimize rate of evaporation.
Recommendation:		Safeguards adequate.

What if?:			Facility is hit by lightning?
Consequence:		Potential to damage tank, piping, or equipment.  Potential release of ammonia.
Safeguards:		Storage area is diked to prevent spreading of spill and to minimize rate of evaporation.
Recommendation:		Safeguards adequate.

What if?:			There is a power outage?
Consequence:		Potentially unable to load or unload.  No safety consequences.
		
What if?:			Vehicle impacts facility?
Consequence;		Potential to damage tank, piping, or equipment.  Potential release of ammonia.	
Safeguards:		Storage area is diked.
Recommendation:		Safeguards adequate.

TRANSPORT			
What if?:			Transport contains something other than aqua?
Consequence:		Potential to contaminate aqua storage, potential to overheat and damage tank from heat of reaction.
Safeguards:		Agreement with supplier to only supply aqua.  Atmospheric vent

inspected during normal operations and deficiencies are reported to the shop foreman.  The facility is inspected periodically by the state Department of Ecology.  Inspection reports are on file in the company office.
4. Maintenance procedures follow.

REMOVE/REPLACE PUMP OR COMPRESSOR

Remove Pump/Compressor:

WARNING:     Before removing/replacing a pump or compressor, ensure that the line segment is vented to atmospheric pressure.

1. Ensure that gas masks and protective clothing are readily available.
2. Ensure line segment which includes pump/compressor is protected from any energy source (i.e. pump/compressor block valves are closed and locked).
3. Ensure breaker for pump/compressor is in off position, tagged, and locked to prevent anyone from inadvertently switching breaker on.
4. Disconnect electrical wiring from pump/compressor.

WARNING:	Ammonia can be very harmful if inhaled.
		Ammonia can cause eye, skin, and respiratory tract burns.
		Always wear splash goggles when working on aqua lines.
		Wear rubber/neoprene safety gloves.
		Always vent line away from you.

5. If there is a vent valve in the line segment, open valve and allow line to vent.  (If there is no vent valve in the line segment, the line segment may be vented from the flanges on the suction and discharge side of the pump/compressor flange as described in Step 6.)
6. Loosen the flange bolts on the side of flange opposite from you (to direct any spray, from residual contents in line, away from you).  Gently pry the flange apart, but only far enough to start the line segment venting. 

CAUTION:	If the line does not stop venting, make sure no other lines are venting into the line segment.  If other lines are not venting to the line segment, a block valve must be leaking and the bulk storage tank may need to be emptied before removing the pump/compressor.

NOTE:     	Procedure, REMOVING AMMONIA FROM TANKS covers depressurizing tanks.

7. Continue by loosening all flange

nsure line segment, which includes gasket is isolated from any energy source. (i.e. block valves are closed and locked and pump motor breaker is locked off).
3. If there is a vent valve in the line segment, open valve and allow line to vent.  (If there is no vent valve in the line segment, the line segment may be vented from the gasketed flange as described in Step 4.)
4. Loosen the flange bolts on the side of flange opposite from you (to direct any spray, from residual contents in line, away from you).  Gently pry the flange apart, but only far enough to start the line segment venting. 
If the line does not stop venting, make sure no other lines are venting into the line segment.  If other lines are not venting to the line segment, a block valve must be leaking and the bulk storage tank may need to be emptied before removing the pump/compressor.

Note:  		Procedure, REMOVING AMMONIA FROM TANKS covers depressurizing tanks.

5. Begin by removing gasket by loosening bolts on opposite side of flanges (to direct any spray, from residual contents in line, away from you).

CAUTION:     	If line not adequately cleaned or purged, STOP, and return to step 3.

6. Continue by loosening all flange bolts
7. Spread flanges to relieve any residual pressure.
8. Remove bolts, separate flanges, and remove gaskets.

Replace Gasket:
1. Inspect gasket and flanges for scratches or defects.

NOTE:     	Do not reinstall gasket with any defects.

2. Clean flanges if necessary.
3. Ensure bolts are proper grade and length.
4. Apply anti-seize compound to bolts.
5. Insert two bolts and slide new gasket into position.
6. Insert remaining bolts and tighten in a cross pattern.
7. Repeat tightening pattern to ensure that all bolts are tight.  (If tightening pattern not repeated, seals may be inadequate and may leak.)
8. Open block valve, and allow line to pressure with ammonia and check for leaks.
9. Clean and store tools.

REMOVE/REPLACE HYDROSTATIC RELIEF VALVE

WA

cking container label.
8. For Temperature gauges installed in temperature wells, fill the well with a non-corrosive liquid such as mineral oil, antifreeze or lightweight grease prior to inserting temperature gauge.

DO NOT use water or ethylene glycol to fill temperature well.

9. Carefully screw threaded gauge/valve into opening.
Avoid cross threading.  After screwing in hand tight, tighten with open end or adjustable wrench.  Do not tighten valve more than 1/2 turn with wrench.

10. Check the position of the gauge.  If the gauge is not properly positioned, turn clockwise until it is in the proper position.

CAUTION:   	Do not turn gauge more than 1/2 turn for positioning purposes.

11. Return tank to service and check for leaks.
12. Clean and store tools.

REMOVING AMMONIA FROM A STORAGE TANKS

This procedure is to permit maintenance that require reducing the tank pressure to 0 psig.  The procedure involves:

1. Removing liquid ammonia from the storage tank to an ammonia transport/nurse tank, then
2. Removing residual ammonia vapor from the storage tank by absorbing the vapor in water in a transport or in another storage tank.

WARNING:     	Ammonia can be very harmful if inhaled.
                        	Ammonia can cause eye, skin, and respiratory tract burns.
		Always wear splash goggles when working on aqua lines.
		Wear rubber/neoprene safety gloves.
		Always vent line away from you.

CAUTION:      	Never leave transfer operation unattended.
		If necessary to leave area, find a qualified person to attend the operation, or stop the operation.

Remove Liquid Ammonia
1. Ensure that gas masks and protective clothing are readily available.
2. Ensure that transport/nurse tanks are approved for ammonia, and transport/nurse tanks are available with enough capacity to hold liquid remaining in storage tank.

ANYHYDROUS AMMONIA should be clearly marked on the transport/nurse tank.

3. Spot the transport/nurse tank.
4. Ensure transpo

POLICY

1. Emergencies are handled by onsite personnel according to the Emergency Shutdown procedure on the following page.
2. Personnel stop leaks or extinguish fires if they can easily control the situation.
3. For more severe situations it is company policy to contact the local fire department and assist as directed by the fire department.

EMERGENCY SHUTDOWN

WARNING:     	Ammonia can be very harmful if inhaled.
                       	Ammonia can cause eye, skin and respiratory tract burns.

Never enter vapor area without respiratory protection, protective gloves, boots, and suit.

MSDS for ammonia is posted on site. For First Aid/Emergency Heath Care, consult MSDS.

1. Warn everyone at facility.
2. If possible, shut down and operating pump or compressor by pushing remote stop button on the start/stop panel or by switching off the breaker.
3. Notify the fire department (911).

	Give your location as: 	Pomeroy Grain Growers.
				290 W. Main.
4. Evacuate persons not required for emergency action and help limit access to the area.  (Evacuate to upwind, or crosswind, location.)
5. If entering affected area.
	A) Put on respiratory protection
	B) Put on gloves, suits, and boots before entering affected area.
	C) If possible, isolate leak by closing appropriate valves.
6. After the emergency has been resolved, and Incident Investigation for must be filled out and kept on file.

In the past five years, we have not had any accidents or releases with off-site consequences.  However, we have instituted an Incident Investigation Policy should a release occur.  

INCIDENT INVESTIGATION POLICY

1. Incidents that resulted in, or could reasonably have resulted in, a catastrophic release are investigated within 48 hours.
2. A report of the investigation is prepared using the Incident Investigation for that follows.  The report is kept on file in the company office for five years.
3. Findings and recommendations from the investigation are promp
